body:
> Why was `void assertAll(Collection<Executable> executables)` not added to the API to begin with?

We originally only supported `Executable...`.

The reason we support `Stream<Executable>` is simply because someone asked for that support.

So, the answer to your question is that we didn't foresee a need for supporting `Collection<Executable>`.

However, I don't see any problem with adding `assertAll(Collection<Executable>)` to the API. We'll simply convert it internally and delegate to existing methods.

rename.from: assertAll taking Collection<Executable> (java) and Collection<() -> Unit> (kotlin)
rename.to: Support Collection<Executable> in Java and Collection<() -> Unit> in Kotlin for assertAll()

rename.from: Support Collection<Executable> in Java and Collection<() -> Unit> in Kotlin for assertAll()
rename.to: Support collections of executables in assertAll()

body:
@JLLeitschuh I'll push the changes for Java to `master`, and I've assigned this issue to you as well in order for you to make the necessary changes to the Kotlin API.

Deal?

On second thought, if we go this route, wouldn't it be better to just support `Iterable<Executable>` instead of `Collection<Executable>`?

@JLLeitschuh would `Iterable<Executable>` work just as well in the Kotlin API?

Never mind... `Iterable<Executable>` doesn't even work in Java since it _clashes_ with `Executable...` which is an array which is also an `Iterable`. 

So we'll just go with `Collection`.

ðŸ˜„ 
I'd be happy to implement the kotlin side unless you want to take a crack at writing some kotlin code yourself. Either way is fine.

I'll try to get to it before Noon EST. I have ~ an hour drive to work and I'm about to leave.

I'll try to do it ASAP and hopefully won't hit any hiccups along the way.

Java Shell example works:
```
jshell
|  Welcome to JShell -- Version 9.0.1
|  For an introduction type: /help intro

jshell> void all(Runnable... args) { for(Runnable a : args) a.run(); }
|  created method all(Runnable...)

jshell> void all(Iterable<Runnable> iter) { for(Runnable a : iter) a.run(); }
|  created method all(Iterable<Runnable>)

jshell> all(() -> System.out.println("Hi"))
Hi

jshell> all(List.of(() -> System.out.println("Hi")))
Hi
```

 Sam tried it on master with the `assertAll` and one more tests failed:
```
/Users/sbrannen/source/junit5/junit-jupiter-engine/src/test/java/org/junit/jupiter/api/AssertAllAssertionsTests.java:133: error: unreported exception IOException; must be caught or declared to be thrown
                        throw new IOException();
```

**Update:**

The Java side of things has been addressed in 61ce1f71befaf00fe3bf0e709a6d78fd3986f726 in `master`.
